Somewhere Only We Know ~ A Professor AU

by rioallalong_719

Summary

Dr. Rio Vidal is the Dean of faculty and Head of the Biological Science Department, a respected and feared leader among her peers. Dr. Agatha Harkness is the witch of the literature department, known for her sharp lectures, powerful stature, and a professor students loved and hated at the same time. The issue: They're secretly married, with only a few close friends knowing.

What happens when young Dr. Wanda Maximoff tries to get with Dr. Harkness? Will Rio blow their cover with her protectiveness? Or will Agatha's pregnancy be the one that breaks the secret love story at West View University?

OR:

A secret marriage between our favorite witch lesbians in a professor AU.

Notes

Don't worry, "Our Love Defies the Cosmos" is still going on. I just couldn't shake this idea and wanted to give you all more fluff. Plus, I LOVE jealous/protective Rio Vidal

Enjoy! ğŸ’šğŸ’œ

Chapter 1: Herbal Promises

She was one of the youngest in her peer group, but unwavering, talented in her lectures, and somehow a rule follower when it came to her dean position. But if you were to ask her students, she was crazy during lab. Completely two different personalities coming out, an enigma, and a lone wolf. â€œMay I remind you, that I have a no cell-phone policy unless it is an emergency which you may take outside. Now, I assume you all completed the notes without issue from my absence on Friday. Wanda

Â 

Wanda sat back on the bench, watching students in the quad move from class to class as their respective periods reigned on. It was during the small faculty mixer before the semester started, professors from all departments in the ballroom at the top of the Student Center. She was in a purple dress, her movement powerful and demanding. She watched as most professors stepped back from her, watching her with hushed whispers before she approached a small group of professors in the corner. Even the one day, Wanda remembered fondly, they both were recruited to judge a debate and it was the closest and longest she had been with her. The air was cold around her, her eyes sharp, attentive to students, but a different warmth came when she praised them. Wanda had tried to drop subtle hints over the monthsâ€“ offering to walk with her to the faculty parking lot after meetings, leaving small compliments here and there about her lectures or the books sheâ€™d chosen for her syllabi. Rio

She watched the ripple, students seeming to realize their peers had stopped talking until there was nothing but silence. She waited it out, wanting them to squirm. William was the first, shifting uncomfortably in his seat and it was enough.Â

Â 

She spoke clearly, listening to furious typing and scratching of paper as she went. She paced herself, hoping to shorten their questioning time, not in the particular mood. She still had to wait, either way, her wife still had one more class after her. Rio paused at one point, waiting for her students as she took a long sip of coffee, pulling at the sweater again.Â 

A knock at the door had her head and all of the other studentsâ€™ heads turned as well. She froze, seeing the new office assistant standing there with a bouquet of black roses. â€œDelivery for Dr. Vidal,â€ the assistant said proudly.Â

â€œAwwww,â€ she heard the chorus behind her.Â

â€œDonâ€™t interrupt my teaching again, unless itâ€™s an emergency. You may go,â€ she flicked her hand dismissively.Â 

The assistant stuttered back, muttering apologies before Rio looked at the roses. They were from her wife to decorate her office with. Â 

â€œAl corazÃ³n negro que late por mÃ­ ~ ğŸ’œ â€

Â 

She fought a smile, but it won in the end, making her turn her back to the students, trying to feign indifference as she set the bouquet carefully on the table.Â

The students straightened in their seats immediately, the tension in the room shifting back to focus. Chapter 5: A Fatal Decision

Chapter Summary

â€œFuck,â€ she cursed as she turned back to Rio, who she knew was already seeing nothing but red.
â€œMove,â€ Rioâ€™s voice was unrecognizable.
It was cold, detached, and it lacked any hint of warmth. It wasnâ€™t something Alice had ever heard, even between the bar fights. This voice was disembodied, something that seemed to drip with an icy lifelessnessâ€“ something that screamed death. Alice couldnâ€™t stop the way her body shivered and flinched away from her friend. â€œDeath.â€

Rio

Â 

She sighed, stepping into her office, the flowers clutched tightly in her hand. The moment her door shut, she leaned forward, smelling the flowers, taking in the sweet floral and scent of the earth. It calmed her, her heart easing for a moment, knowing her wife was okay and she would see her soon. She did end class earlier, and left after answering a few questions. She had two hoursâ€“ two hours to fill her time before she could go see her wife. It wasnâ€™t long, but she already felt like the clock hands were purposely dragging, elongating time and twisting a knife into her wandering thoughts. The freshmen had Agatha in thirty minutes and something about how she had already lost her patience todayâ€“ well, she wouldnâ€™t blame her wife if she snapped at them too.Â 

Rio set her bag down before unwrapping the green paper around the bouquet. Setting the card on her desk, she slipped the rubberband off the stems, avoiding the thorns as she turned to the large vase on her desk, already standing with red roses from her wife a couple of weeks ago. She had a long day and somehow, her wife knew and sent her flowers. The red petals were slightly curling, their edges tinged with black, announcing the entrance to their next life. She took them out, setting them aside before taking the vase and changing the water. One of the teenagers from her class came in slowly, his MacBook firmly in hold as he glanced around her office before meeting her eye. Bird week was before finals, something to lessen the studentsâ€™ nerves. She would teach about the different types of birds and how to classify some of them through their beaks and the type of food they ate. Rio had her fair share of finals weeks, many spent in tears, sometimes working herself up so much, she was puking at three am after a study session. He shook his head, â€œNo, I study Latin.â€Â 

She quirked a small smile, â€œI did too when I went to Harvard. Now, what is troubling you with bryophytes and their antheridium?â€Â 

Â 

The questions werenâ€™t bad from the teen. She explained it with ease, before eventually, making her way to her whiteboard and drawing out the diagrams. Â 

â€œAny other questions, Mr. Kaplan? Worst is that I can write an excuse for your next class.â€Â

THEY MATCH EACH OTHER'S FREAK

See the end of the chapter for more notes

Rio stared out into the backyard. Her eyes watching the branches lay bare and naked, their leaves dusting the ground as the pines stood firm and strong. The green was beautiful, showcasing their raw power and understanding of the cold. She loved the fall. She loved watching the squirrels find the last of their nuts, the hummingbirds picking at the last of the flowers, and most of all the owls. She wasnâ€™t sure why, but the owls always seemed to love her yard. They were always surrounding her house, something almost like that one scene in the first Harry Potter movie.Â 

She cradled her hot cup of tea in her hands, warming her as she adjusted the blanket. It was mid afternoon, the sun was high, the days were cold, almost too cold for fall. Her wife was fast asleep in their bed, where Rio had led her the moment they got home from the bar. They didnâ€™t speak of what happened, no, Rio didnâ€™t want to break the moment. The moment they had both showered, Agatha crawled straight into her arms, burying her face into her neck, and refusing to let go. It was eleven in the morning when she woke up herself, but it was a struggle to get out of her wifeâ€™s grip. She would have stayed if her bladder gave her the choice. Yet, for a moment she couldnâ€™t will herself to go back to bed. She had work to do, but worse was the impending conversation. She wasnâ€™t mad, not at Agatha, but something gnawed at her that couldnâ€™t be entirely mad at Wanda. Her friends were right. Neither had worn their rings while at work, who was she to get mad if someone flirted with either of them.Â 

Rio looked down at the giant amethyst on her finger. It was a symbol of Agatha, to be always carrying Agathaâ€™s love with her. She remembered it vividly as if it was yesterday. They both were working for their PhD when Rio was leaning against the door, watching her girlfriend work and for some reason, in that scene, with the lamp light making Agathaâ€™s hair shine, she had muttered, what she thought was underneath her breath, â€œGoddess, I want to marry you.â€ Agatha had heard her, and it was there, on that spot, even without rings, Agatha had said â€œyes.â€ Seriously, her girlfriend had simply turned around, looked her dead in the eye and said â€œyes.â€ Weeks later, they went to a jeweler and customized their rings, agreeing to always carry a piece of each other. It wasnâ€™t what Rio planned. She had some ideas how she wanted to propose to her, but in her moment of awe of the woman before her, she had let her thoughts slip.Â 

But it was perfect, it was everything, it was so utterly and undeniably them.Â 

Rio smiled softly, the memory lingering like a quiet whisper. Agathaâ€™s unexpected â€œyesâ€ had still caught her by surprise, but in the best way. There had been no elaborate plan, no fireworks or grand gestures. Just the two of them, surrounded by the soft glow of a lamp, and the unspoken connection that had always existed between them. It was a simple, pure momentâ€“ the kind that made everything feel right.Â 

Rio sipped her tea, savoring the warmth as it slid down her throat, a small comfort as the coldness of fall settled around her. Her mind wandered back to the night beforeâ€“ the bar, the tension in the air, and the way Agatha had clung to her as if she were the only thing holding her together. It made Rioâ€™s heart ache in the best way, knowing how deeply their connection ran. Yet, there had been something unsettling in the air too, something lingering like a shadow that had followed them home.Â 

She glanced at the door back into her home, wondering if she was still asleep, tucked under the covers and cradling her stomach. Rio couldnâ€™t help but wonder if Agatha had been processing the same thing. Would they talk about it later? She wasnâ€™t sure if she was ready. Not yet. But she wasnâ€™t angry, not really. She knew Wandaâ€™s flirtation was harmless, even if it stungâ€¦ okay, yes it made her pissed. The real issue was the silent, unspoken tension between themâ€“ the stuff that hadnâ€™t been said but was felt by both.Â 

Rio leaned back against the cushion of the outdoor swing, her fingers tracing the hot surface of her mug. She rubbed the amethyst ring on her finger again, a small, quiet smile tugging at her lips. Agatha had simply said â€œyes,â€ with no hesitation. No doubt. And that was all Rio had ever wantedâ€“ her, always.Â 

Her thoughts were interrupted by a loud yell, â€œRio Harkness-Vidal!â€Â 

Rio jumped, nearly spilling the tea as she scrambled to get the blanket she had wrapped tightly around her off. She cursed, standing up, allowing it to fall to the wood of their back porch and setting the mug on the table before running inside. She slid the glass door open, closing it behind her, searching for her wife. Her heart was pounding wildly, looking around the room before making her way into the living room to find it empty. Confused, worry filling her, she turned, thinking her wife must still be in bed, until a body slammed into hers. She sucked in a breath of surprise, before relaxing. Rio smiled softly as Agatha settled against her, still half-asleep and wrapped in the warmth of their embrace. Her fingers instinctively brushed over Agathaâ€™s stomach, the faintest bump just beginning to show, and the touch felt like both a promise and a new chapter in their lives. She pressed a gentle kiss to Agathaâ€™s forehead, savoring the quiet intimacy of the moment. But the softness of it melted away as she felt something wet against the crook of her neck. She gasped, pulling her wife closer, not understanding the tears.Â 

â€œAgatha? Whatâ€™s wrong?â€Â 

Agatha sniffled, though her voice was already gaining its usual sharpness.Â 

â€œI thought you disappeared,â€ she muttered, her tone shifting to one of irritation. â€œWoke up and you werenâ€™t there. Where the hell did you go?â€Â 

Rio froze for a moment, then let out a soft breath, â€œI was just outside on the swing, my love. I didnâ€™t want to disturb you while you were sleeping.â€Â

Rio felt a wave of tenderness mixed with a little amusement knowing exactly what was going on. She knew the mood swings would be rough, especially with Agatha Harkness, but she didnâ€™t expect the whiplash of anger, crying, and then irritation the moment her wife woke up.

â€œYou were asleep. I didnâ€™t think youâ€™d even notice.â€

â€œI noticed,â€ Agatha muttered, rubbing her eyes and brushing away the last of the tears. â€œI didnâ€™t like it.â€Â 

Rio smirked softly, â€œIâ€™m right here now. Youâ€™re not alone.â€ She tightened her arms around Agatha. â€œNot going anywhere.â€

Agatha grumbled under her breath, but a small, quiet acceptance seemed to settle within her.Â 

â€œWhatever. Just donâ€™t disappear again,â€ she huffed.Â 

Rio leaned down and kissed the top of Agathaâ€™s head, feeling the weight of her wifeâ€™s emotions without needing the words.Â 

â€œI wonâ€™t,â€ she whispered, â€œPromise.â€Â 

Agatha huffed again but didnâ€™t pull away. Instead, her wife burrowed into the crook of her neck, refusing to let go. Rio couldnâ€™t stop the smile on her face.Â 

This is going to be a long pregnancy.Â 

But Rio wouldnâ€™t have it any other way.Â

They didnâ€™t talk right away about the night before, it was too soon, and with Agathaâ€™s mood swings, Rio wasnâ€™t ready to risk it until her wife said something. Rio didnâ€™t try to move this time, knowing her wife needed this. William and Ireland exchanged glances as the doors slammed behind the professor. Her footsteps were loud, her usually stoic face now held her eyebrows pinched together. Chapter 8: The Little Alien

Chapter Summary

â€œMmm, the little alien wants more,â€ Rio teased, her smile widening. â€œHow about I go make some tea and slice up an apple or two? Keep that growing alien happy.â€

Â 

OR:

Their first ultrasound and Lilia and Alice reacting

Chapter Notes

SURPRISE-- I had one class today and yesterday I went skiing, so my body is dying

I hope you like this, i don't think this is my finest work, I had imagined it soo many different ways, I struggled to put it to words.

See the end of the chapter for more notes

She hummed softly, a softer and deeper breath tickling her neck as she shifted slightly, pressing a gentle kiss in a curly brunette mane. Rio was pinned in place, her arms stiff and her bad knee ached with a fathom pain telling her to straighten it. She did slowly, wincing slightly as it cracked before a warmer leg was holding her in place again. She rolled her eyes fondly, the head against her neck nuzzling closer to her, as if to fuse with her very own body. Her shirt was tightened in Agathaâ€™s hand, the other mindless drumming her fingers on Rioâ€™s sternum. Rio continued humming as she stared at her phone over Agathaâ€™s head, trying to read her emails for today. The past couple of days, she found her wife more cuddly. It was strange, Agatha usually liked her space most of the time, except for when they were in bed at night where both of them would swap being little spoons. However, something changed starting Monday, after they got home from work.Â 

Â 

Rio had set her papers down on the dining room table before going into the kitchen and starting dinner. It was Agathaâ€™s turn, but she needed this. She figured her wife didnâ€™t want to talk after she got upset at her for snapping and keeping things â€˜unprofessional.â€™ It led to a small fight in Rioâ€™s own office during lunch, and both of them were in a foul mood for the rest of the day. Of course, during her studentsâ€™ quiz, she decided to take her mind off it by looking at baby things: cribs, carriers, toys, little outfits, a perfect stroller she already put in her cart, and even baby names. That was until a student approached with their quiz and she was snapped back to her reality of her wife and she had fought. The drive home was quiet. They didnâ€™t speak, knowing the other one was finally cooling off and taking time to reflect.Â 

Making dinner relaxed her, her frustration coming to a halt as she prepared, grabbing the ingredients, potatoes, bacon, chicken broth, and some cream cheese. She started off simple, cutting up the potatoes and placing them in the broth before starting the stove. The bacon was next and just as she got them to cool, she went to turn, grabbing her bottle of water, warm hands wrapped around her waist, causing her to jump. She turned slowly, finding her wife but before she could see her face, it was buried into the crook of her neck. Warmth encircled her, lips pressed lazily against her neck as she slowly wrapped her arms back around her. Agatha murmured something against her neck, and the only reason she knew was the slight vibration there.Â 

â€œWhat did you say, mi amor ?â€ she asked quietly.Â 

â€œIâ€™m sorry.â€Â 

Agatha Harkness apologisingâ€¦ while it wasnâ€™t unheard of, it certainly was rare after their fights. Normally, her wife would do something for her, like buy her plants, a ridiculously expensive necklace or bracelet, or packets of the freeze-dried strawberries she adored and could easily eat without stopping. When they werenâ€™t fighting, Agatha had to hide the packets, making Rio have to ask for them like a child. It infuriated her, but her wife had a point. So apologising, instead of gift-giving caught her completely off guard.Â 

â€œWhat?â€ she couldnâ€™t help but ask.Â 

Her wife scoffed, but kept firmly against her, â€œYou heard me. Donâ€™t push your luck.â€Â 

Â 

Rio didnâ€™t but her wife was firmly attached to her the rest of that night. It was strange, in the most loving way possible. Agatha didnâ€™t leave her once she did apologize, instead, stayed leaning against her as she finished dinner. When they did eat, her wife was holding her hand. When Rio went to clean up, Agatha scowled at her until she sat down on the couch. In seconds, she was curled up against her side. Hell, Rio couldnâ€™t even shower alone without her wife following her and holding onto her. By Tuesday morning, Agatha had somehow wormed her way on top of Rio, but the only issue was getting the woman out of bed and getting to work on time, which they were both late. During their lunch, her wife insisted on sitting on the couch and then leaned into her the whole time. And the previous night, it was the repeat of the night before.Â 

Now, Rio laid on her side, Agatha trying to somehow fuse their bodies together as she dozed in and out of sleep. One point earlier in the morning, Rio had gotten up to pee and the moment she was close enough to the bed again, Agatha dragged her in. Who would have thought pregnancy would make Agatha Harkness clingy?Â 

Rio shifted again, the stray hairs from her wifeâ€™s head tickling her chin. There was nothing new from work, but as Rio glanced at the time, she realized she had to start waking her wife to get to the ultrasound in time. She turned off her phone, placing soft kisses on her wifeâ€™s head, knowing she would get the kindest response that way.Â 

â€œ Mi vida, itâ€™s time to wake up. We have to leave soon,â€ she spoke softly.Â 

Agatha huffed her annoyance, but instead of pulling away, she pulled Rio closer against her, refusing to let go, â€œFuck off.â€Â 

Rio chuckled, kissing down to her cheek before tucking her hair behind her ear. Leaning forward she whispered softly, â€œThe ultrasound is today, mi vida. We get to see our baby.â€Â 

Her wife sat up, her hair a mess as she grabbed Rioâ€™s phone looking at the time. Without another word, she stood walking to the bathroom. Rio waited a moment before catching her wife was fine. She made her way into the kitchen, putting in toast and starting tea. Excitement ran through her, she was practically bouncing as she waltzed into their room, going through her draws to fish out her sweat pants, only to find her favorite pair missing. Cursing to herself, she found her black ones, putting them on and adding a dark green long sleeve.Â 

Walking into the bathroom she spoke, â€œ Mi amor, have you seen my green sweatpants? I swore I put themâ€“â€

She froze, seeing her wife brushing her hair in the mirror wearing none other than the green sweatpants she was looking for. â€œNo, sorry, my love,â€ she teased, her voice still thick with sleep, before looking up at her through the mirror.Â

Rio blinked, momentarily caught off guard, before quickly shaking herself from her stupor. Yet, every time she saw her wife in her clothes, there was something that made her heart stutter, a flutter in her chest that never got old. She fought to keep the blush from rising up her neck, her pulse quickening with that all-too-familiar warmth spreading through her veins.Â 

As the minutes ticked by, Rio found herself sneaking glances at her wife, each one feeling like a stolen moment. Agatha was stunning, radiating a quiet beauty that seemed to grow with every passing day. And today, they were about to see their baby for the first time. Even though their little one was still the size of a grape, the excitement was undeniable. In the car, Rioâ€™s nerves were a whirlwind, her emotions jumping from anxiety to excitement with every beat of her heart. RioÂ

Rio

She stared at the door, breath shallow, hands clenched at her side. She could hear Agatha moving insideâ€“ shuffling, the rustle of blankets, the sharp intake of breath that meant she was crying but trying not to. Rio wanted to fight. Wanted to completely blow the door off its hinges, fall to her knees, and beg Agatha to hear herâ€¦to explain, to fix it. But what was there to fix? She knew Agatha heard her by the way she had gone still, not a sound behind the door now. With an unsteady exhale, she pulled away. Agatha told her to sleep on the couch. So she would. Even if it felt like a death sentence.Â 

Her body was pure weight as she moved down the hall, each step protesting under her as she turned off the lights in a broken haze. When she fell to the couch, she found it uncomfortable, but it didnâ€™t matter, because Rio deserved it. She failed. She hurt herâ€¦ how the fuck was she supposed to be a good mother? With that, she curled into herself, hoping to block the weight in her chest, but it didnâ€™t stop. She turned, grabbing a pillow and burying her face into it, tryingâ€“ failingâ€“ to stop the tears burning at her eyes. She never cried, not like this. This was a different pain, something she never felt before. And it was all her fault.Â 

Rio pushed away the only person in the world she cared about, the only person in the whole universe that she loved. Agatha was Rioâ€™s everything. She was the earth, sun, sea, and stars. Sure, she had her friends and Oriana was the closer sister, but no one compared to Agatha. She swore the woman knew her better than she knew herself.Â 

Rio clawed at herself, hating that she hurt her, hating at who she was. If only she could have been stronger, to be able to suck it up, and would have just held her damn wife like she requested. She was carrying her child and Divine Motherâ€“ Rio couldnâ€™t breathe.Â 

She sat up, cradling her knees to her chest, the pillow now tucked between her knees and chest as she screamed her sobs into it. She couldnâ€™t shake the hurricane of thoughts, the way her own mind felt like a hive of angry wasps, stinging their own home, and leaving nothing but hurt. She was going to fail as a mother. This childâ€“ gods, this child was going to hate her. She wasnâ€™t enough for either of them. She choked again, clawing for breath, but refusing to lift her head from the pillow.Â 

Her hands shook, desperately clutching the pillow tighter as if it could somehow tether her to reality. Every thought felt like a dagger to her heartâ€“ sharp and relentless. The stinging, overwhelming guilt refused to leave. Her wife just needed her, Agatha who hated being vulnerable, who hated voicing what she needed, voiced what she needed and Rio just pushed her away. She wasnâ€™t the rock she promised to be, she wasnâ€™t the partner her wife deserved. She thought of their first date, how Agatha had made her feel seen, feel whole. Rio couldnâ€™t remember a time when Agatha wasnâ€™t in her heart, so deep it was embedded in her very soul. The idea of losing herâ€“ of failing herâ€“ was unbearable.Â 

She squeezed her eyes shut, trying to block out the image of Agathaâ€™s face, how her wife had pulled back, as if she had been burned by Rioâ€™s touch. Every word Agatha had spoken in that fragile, broken voice echoed in Rioâ€™s mind, cutting deeper with each replay.Â 

Why couldnâ€™t I just be here for her? she wondered.Â 

The answer was simple. She wasnâ€™t enough. Not strong enough, not kind enough, not patient enough. She had always been one to keep her walls, to shut people outâ€“ worse than her wife. She learned to turn off her emotions, to just be something powerful, void of emotionâ€¦ fuck, she had even shut Agatha out at times before. She had learned to survive by shutting off parts of herself, to keep people at arms lengthâ€“ cause in the end, they would just leave whether it was the road to death or just not being able to understand herâ€¦ but she never realized the damage that would cause to the one that mattered most. Agatha had always given, always trusted her, and she had repaid that by being distant when her wife needed her warmth the most.Â 

Her chest ached, a deep, raw ache she had no words for, but the pain of it was consuming. Rio wrapped her arms around herself tighter, desperate for comfort that wasnâ€™t coming.Â 

She ruined everything.Â 

All in one day, the universe stopped working around her. A single frayed threadâ€¦ it was pulled and her natural order of life dismantled. Chapter End Notes

Also, I did a shit ton of research on Yule. I want to celebrate Yule one day, but I grew up in a christian household like so I have been trying to explore more Pagan roots. if you guys have any notes on Yule, please send them my way.

Also, we are just going to pretend that the bone marrow way is capable of producing the Y chromosome. I thought about IVF, but then I figured "made from scratch" so like made from Rio's bone marrow and that it just tied well together with her also being Lady Death. I believe scientists are still working on the bone marrow method of pro-creating, but it also just seemed very AgathaRio to me.

Yes, I jumped on Rio's parents are dead train, but ya know, we love abuelitas sooooo, more Vidal family incoming and Yuletide festivities and soon the 18 week scan. (was gonna do more for this chapter, but then I hit 9k words and was like I need to calm down)

Finally, I realized I fucked up. I wanted Rio to have tattoos, but idk if it would be weird to mention them now ? let me know what you guys think

â€œGoddess, she knew you were our son before I even did,â€ she whispered in awe, her chest aching now.Â Â

Â 

Whatever secret Rio was holding, Agatha knew sheâ€™d have to trust that her wife would unveil it in her own time. But Agatha Harkness was not a woman known for her patience. It was only a matter of time before the tension inside her reached its breaking point, and when it did, the storm that followed would be impossible to ignore.

Students

Â 

Ryan had a secret.Â 

A horrible secret that he even kept from his friendsâ€¦ something that ate at him throughout all of winter break. Yet, it was no secret that Ryan wasnâ€™t particularly the brightest, but he was trying. He was trying so hard for his family and most importantly his little sister who was in middle school and looked up to him. So when a chance showed up that his little sister would get a good word in with Dartmouth University, how was he supposed to say no? It was stupid really. He didnâ€™t understand how he fell for it, but pulled all nighters, nose buried in a textbook, desperate to understand the major he choseâ€“ in the moment, it felt like the right call.Â 

It was supposed to be small, something inconsequential. Students had their fun with rumors all the time and Dr. Harkness and Dr. Vidal barely seemed fazed with the marriage rumors, even though he was dead set it was true. So what harm could a little baby rumor start? Dr. Maximoff had approached him, promising recommendation letters, before finally threatening to cut him from the football teamâ€“ something to keep him in line before telling him what she overheard. He thought nothing but of his career and of his futureâ€¦ so he let the words slip, careless whispers turned wildfire, crackling through the halls of the university.Â 

At first, it was just a joke. A harmless little thing, nothing but a whisper in passingâ€“ Dr. Vidal, pregnant? It was almost laughable. She was the most no-nonsense professor on campus, the kind of woman who could silence a lecture hall with a single glance. The idea of her, of the Dean herself, carrying a child? It felt absurd. But then it spread, mutating, twisting into something beyond his control. He hadnâ€™t thought much of it when Dr. Maximoff first pulled him aside, her tone all honeyed promises and veiled threats. A letter of recommendation, a future at Dartmouth securedâ€“ and all he had to do was repeat what she had overheard. Just a little rumor, nothing more.Â 

And Ryan, desperate and foolish, had taken the bait. Now, it was everywhere. Professors constantly congratulated Vidal at finals week and at first, yeah it was funny. Seeing how pissed she got, how she snapped at other brilliant minds. In his defense, he did not take responsibility for what Ireland did. That was all her and he and the others had tried stopping her. What person in their right mind went up to someone, accusing them of being pregnant when they werenâ€™t showing, they hadnâ€™t even said anything, and when it wasnâ€™t even a concrete fact whether she was married? So, no, Ryan didnâ€™t have guilt for that. Despite Ryan not being the brightest person when it came to books, he was sure it took simple common sense not to do that.Â 

But the rumors turned, building up continuously like ripples. Professors and students whispered alike that Dr. Harkness was using Dr. Vidal, sleeping her way through the faculty. Despite Harkness being scary, Ryan enjoyed the professorâ€™s lectures, even if most of the time he was confused. â€œDr. Maximoff,â€ he said, taking another step when she stepped forward, the smile on her face too bright, too forced.Â

He nodded his head, â€œGreatâ€“ yep, great.â€

She nodded her head slowly, her head tilting and it was communicated clearly, I know you are trying to tell Dr. Harkness. Utter one breath, and your football career is gone.Â

Agatha

Â 

Twenty-two weeks pregnant, not even two weeks into the spring semester, her wife was still hiding something. Agatha had been surprisingly patient, well if you count patience as the fact that she was actually too exhausted the moment they stepped home. The moment she was in the comfort of her own home, Rio took them to their room, either ran a hot bath or hopped in the shower with her, before laying her down to take a nap. She would fall asleep with half her body on her wife, fingers running through the ends of her hair, a hand on her stomach or Rio would be tucking pillows around her, Agatha refusing to buy an actual pillow made for her, as she always wanted to cling to Rio. She didnâ€™t want her wife forcing a pillow at her when it wasnâ€™t warm like Rio, when she couldnâ€™t listen to the steady heartbeat underneath her ear, nor have her head rise and fall with her wifeâ€™s chest.

So when the pillows were set, Rio would sit on the floor, her hands on Agathaâ€™s stomach, muttering soft Spanish that Agatha was too tired to comprehend. And when her eyes were too heavy, a kiss would be pressed to her stomach, her forehead, her nose, and finally to her lips and Rio, the sneaky bastard, would slip away.Â 

And this was when Agatha hated being pregnant. She hated constantly feeling like her emotions were crazy, constantly not having a grasp on themâ€“ always overreacting, between snapping at her wife or crying over something simple.

She was reading a passage about Ophelia, comparing the original text to movie with the understanding agencyâ€“ of Ophelia taking the narrative and whether her death was truly a suicide or something on accident. The passage was highlighting the floral imagery of her death in the original text, talking of her mermaid, haunting-like appearance in the brooke surrounded by flowers, and for whatever reason, Agatha thought back to her wife. She thought of the flowers Rio got her for every date up till they were married, even now, Rio would love surprising every now and then with flowers. And with that thought, her throat tightened up. It was embarrassing, the tears welling in her eyes as she had to take a few calming breaths before continuing. For once, the little fucking brats kept their mouths shut.Â 

And she hated her strange cravings. She hated wanting to eat pickles with ice cream, mac & cheese with applesauce, the random Nandoâ€™s cravingsâ€“ or especially craving that one pastry from a cafÃ© twenty minutes away from campus and it absolutely ruined her day when neither she or Rio could get them. She hated that she was stealing Rioâ€™s portion of lunch too. She hated waking up her wife at three am, begging her to go get one of the cravings, and then having to wait in a cold bed for her to come back absolutely exhausted.Â 

Then came the pains, when her back would kill her, aching from carrying the new weight of their son. She hated that her fingers were starting to swell, that Rio had to pry her wedding ring off of her with dish soap and then having to wear it around her neck along with the Triple Goddess necklace. EvanoraÂ

Evanora had spent her life crafting perfection, each move precise, each achievement another jewel in her crown. Influence? Unmatched.Â

Agatha

Â

She didnâ€™t notice, no, she was somewhere else, feeling him press against the palm of her hand, announcing his presence. She tried moving her hand in circles, hoping he would settle, but he only responded with another kick, as if reveling in his ability to throw her off balance. She almost chuckled, but she stifled it with a soft hum, realizing she desperately needed to finish the reading. The students were staring at her now, expectantâ€“ but mostly confused, but for some reason, she couldnâ€™t pull herself out of her shock.Â 

â€œDr. Harkness?â€ a voice finally cut through to her.Â 

She snapped her head up, looking up at William.Â 

â€œAre you alright?â€Â 

She nodded her head, â€œYes, go ahead and finish the passage and then whenever you are ready, get into small groups and discuss the relationship between Caliban and Prospero. And then, go back through and highlight passages like this one that underlines the ideas of power and colonization.â€

Agatha sat back in a chair she had recently brought in when she taught. Â She flipped absentmindedly through the book, rubbing her stomach as her son continued to press against her palm. Tiny punches landed like she was training the next Muhammad Ali. Another push against her palm made her freeze, staring down at her stomach expectedly.

He didnâ€™t. He just turned in her stomach, maybe a hand pushing against her this time. She would have to talk to Abuelita and see if she knew what Rio was like in the womb. She felt her eyebrows pinch together as he continued. The students noticed. They werenâ€™t saying anythingâ€“ oh, of course not. They got their freebee on the first day. She turned a page in her book without reading a single word. A few students exchanged wary glances. One of themâ€“ Cassandra, or maybe Carolinaâ€“ tilted her head slightly, as if on the verge of speaking, but thought better of it. Smart girl.Â 

Another nudge made Agatha jump in surprise, her head snapping down to her stomach again, Not now, love, please. Mama needs to get through this.

â€œStart the discussion,â€ she instructed, her voice thinner than she wouldâ€™ve liked. â€œI donâ€™t want to hear silence.â€Â

Students

Rio

Â 

Pain scorched through her side as she blinked through the blinding lights of the ambulance. â€œAnd lifting things?â€ Rio started, already thinking of the laundry she had been doing to stop her wife from walking the stairs.Â

Rio went straight for the couch, slowly easing herself down and closing her eyes. Before she could move to get up, the couch dipped beside her, a hand caressing her cheek. She didnâ€™t bother opening her eyes, leaning into the caress as if the touch could soothe the tidal of thoughts into gentle lapping waves.Â

Rio sighed, the image of the blade being raised to throw at her wife flashing through her mind. She rolled her eyes at that, but felt herself fall further into the cushions, her eyelids heavy. She couldnâ€™t stop the guilt from capturing her, and no, it was not over her mother-in-lawâ€™s deathâ€“ part of it was regret, not being able to enjoy the moment she snuffed out the worthless life and not realizing how hard her elbow had landed. If she could go back, she would enjoy killing the cunt. But for now, she took the win that she was dead, the cops trying to sweep it under the rug that they messed up by not providing medical care immediately, and really, her and her wife couldnâ€™t give two fucking shits. All she knew was that Evanora was dead. She couldnâ€™t hurt her wife anymore and she would never get the chance to hurt their son. Chapter 25: Her Protectrice

Agatha

Â 

It was still dark outside, yet the birds were already humming their morning melodies through the chasm of a frozen wonderland. The wind had howled all through the night, making the house groan, shaking shutters, and rattling loose shingles. Frozen ashes had waltzed from the heaven, somber and delicateâ€“ mocking the stars as moved in Februaryâ€™s unforgiving grasp. It was colder than had been in weeksâ€“ yet February had never been known for its gentleness despite what the stars produced, still Agatha had long since forgiven the frigid month, for it had given her something far more eternal than death : her favorite person. Born beneath ancient constellations of Cetus and Andromeda, and Pegsus and Piscesâ€“ a woman of seafoam and moonlight. A Pisces, the most romantic of them all. Her lovergirl. Her protectrice. Her steady river of life. And before her pregnancy, she called Rio the weighted blanket that bit her.

She would be lying to herself if she said she didnâ€™t crave the pressure of her wife draped over her body, pinning her into the mattress (not like that you freaks, yes I am talking to you) half-asleep nibblingâ€“ her shoulder, the soft arc of her collarbones, and most of the time her breasts if they were easy access. Her wife was like a giant cat mixed in with a piranha, all tongue or all teeth, covering her in her affections and devotion. Just a consequence of marrying Rio Vidal. But now, especially with her large belly, the roles were reversedâ€¦ minus the biting. Her head was always resting on her wifeâ€™s chest, listening to the rhythm of her wifeâ€™s black beating heart, their legs entangled softly like kelpe braiding itself together just beneath the surfaceâ€¦ but that was before the wound, both emotionally and physically.Â Â Â Â 

The emotional bruise was beginning to fade, yes, but Agatha knew better than to believe that yesterdayâ€™s apologies could fill a canyon. So she did what she knew best, the ancient language that both she and Rio understood by heart : love, expressed through acts of service and offerings given not out of duty, but out of devotion. So she had risen at six, before the sun and her worshippers, and despite not having to leave until ten thanks to a two hour weather delayâ€¦ she might have to call Alice and ask her to clear their driveway if the snow was tall. She hadnâ€™t checked. She had other priorities this morning.Â 

She had already ordered flowers to be sent to her wifeâ€™s desk : carnations, tulips, Babyâ€™s Breath, violets, with a single azalea in the center. She remembered Rio telling her carnations were for mothersâ€“ a symbole of motherhood and deep familia love. The tulips were easy, a message of her own love and devotion for her wife. The Babyâ€™s Breath was for their little one and the violetsâ€¦ something to make her wife chuckle as giving a sprig of violets as in the late 19th and early 20th century, worshippers of Sappho in Paris wore them on their clothes. Finally, the azaleaâ€“ to symbolise that she, in turn, would promise to love Rio with all the gentleness in the world she deserved. She had the florist leave a note :Â

To my protectrice. To my love. To the mother of my child ~ ğŸ’œA

She set the homemade fries aside, stealing a few that were already cool before cracking the eggs into the pan with one hand, her other on her back. Chapter End Notes

Also, sorry for taking so long. My dog is super old and needs some extra love between getting up and down steps and attention.

For those of you who saw my post on twt, she is okay. She has lived a long, healthy, and loving life so far. I am cherishing these days I have left with her.

Ironically, life really hit today. Today, my last goat passed on to the next life. Rest easy, buddy. He was the oldest goat we have ever had. He lived over 18 years, gorging on fresh grass and any of our vegetable left overs. Just wanted to share.

Finally, out curiosity and because I would love to hear from you all, what are your theories for how the birth will go with Nicky ? Keep in mind he WILL be alive at the end !
